comments:
N20050607-0010

I can no longer launch any target from my dev workspace. Also tried adding a new
Eclipse launch config but no luck.

Did what I always do with a new drop:
1. installed N20050607-0010 to fresh dir
2. started my existing dev workspce
3. imported existing unshared plug-ins as binary project from N20050607-0010
   (not linked)
4. started my target
==> doesn't come up

Here's how to reproduce this out of the box:

1. install N20050607-0010 to fresh directory
2. start fresh workspace
3. import org.eclipse.jdt.ui and all required plug-ins as binary projects from 
   N20050607-0010 (not linked)
   NOTE: the scenario works if I install ALL plug-ins
4. On the PDE Target Platform preference page disable all external plug-ins
5. create a new Eclipse Application launch config
   ==> application "org.eclipse.ui.ide.workbench" is chosen as program
6. Run
==> doesn't start, see .log below

NOTE: same scenario works just fine using N20050606-0010 even if I import from
N20050606-0010.

Info as requested in comment 1

I just tried the scenario again and it's reproducible for me every time. Maybe
one of my steps is unclear? Do you need more detailed steps?

let me try this first:  what does the 'Validate Plugin Set' tell you on the 
Plugins tab of the launch configuration?

Well, your platform.xml looks bad.  It only lists org.apache.ant.  No wonder 
you couldn't launch.

That all is just fine, which it probably is: if I exit that new workspace,
restart with N20050606-0010 the launch config works and the target is launched.
Note that the attached zip is from the fresh install + fresh workspace.

This certainly not a runtime issue.  Moving to Update.
Note: the dev.properties and config.ini that are generated look fine.

I am getting an error using last night's build. The platform.xml is:
  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> 
- <config date="1118151138647" transient="true" version="3.0">

I don't understand why only the org.apache.ant is included, but that's 
certainly a bug. The only changes that went into the configurator were those 
related to relative paths, but, to me, this looks like a slightly different 
problem. I think the PDE team should also look at their usage of the update 
API, to make sure things are invoked correctly, especially with respect to 
paths.

Wassim, one problem that may be the causethis is related to the recent change in
PDE to avoid duplicating sites when the device letter changes.

The paths are being normalized when the local sites are created, but the
comparison that decides whether a new site is needed is not doing the same. So
it ends up trying to add every plug-in in the workspace to a different site
(with the same actual URL). Update will silently refuse any of the additional
sites, so the configuration has only one of the plug-ins from the workspace.

The first paragraph in the comment above should read:

"Wassim, this is related to the recent change in PDE to avoid duplicating sites
when the device letter changes."

I could verify that adding the following two lines at the beginning of
TargetPlatform#addToSite fixes the problem.

if (path.getDevice() != null)
  path = path.setDevice(path.getDevice().toUpperCase(Locale.ENGLISH));

The problem is only reproducible if the workspace is on FAT32 (that seems to
affect the the case for device letters). Has anyone seen this with an workspace
on NTFS?

The file system thing might be a red herring. Jerome was seeing the same problem
on NTFS (bug 98650).
Mine is NTFS.
*** Bug 98650 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
what about device name?  I am running on D and I don't see the problem.

I am running on "D" as well. In my case, the site path for plug-ins in the
workspace have a lowercase "d".

Created an attachment (id=22521)
Platform.xml

I am really puzzled by the randomness of it all.
Doing Dani's scenario on a fresh 0607 install, this is the platform.xml I get. 
It looks and runs fine.  Note the uppercase D.

In any event, the two lines in comment 10 should certainly be there regardless.
I just released that code to close this bug.

Of course, we would have none of these problems and we would not need all 
these workarounds for IPath comparisons if bug 49516 were addressed one way or 
another.

Are the site paths PDE maintains built from
IProject.getLocation().removeLastSegments(1)? I noticed in my workspace the
project path has a lower case device letter, but in Pascal's case (he could not
reproduce the problem), project location paths had upper case device letters.
For workspace plugins, yes.

The trigger is the way you provide you workspace location. The path provided
there is the base for file system paths provided by using IResource.getLocation().
Yes, I have problem if I launch with -data d:... and not when with -data D:...
